rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Isolation and identification of some lignin constituents.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Lignin, since it forms quite an appreciable part of woody and other plant tissues, has naturally given rise to a great deal of research, and dating from the investigations of Cross and Bevan (beginning about 1896) in England, work in this field has become quite intensive. Yet, the information available is exceedingly limited and indefinite, the nature of the reactions of lignin very vague, and the conclusions drawn as to the arrangement of the atoms, or groups of atoms within its molecule mostly speculative. Whether lignin contains a benzenoid nucleus, or is entirely aliphatic in character, has not yet been solved. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The milling industry in Canada.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: In introducing a subject like "The Flour Milling Industry in Canada" we must realize the important position which it holds in Canada's economic life. Figures for the past year show that the Industry ranked second among all the industries of the country from the point of view of the value of its product. Hence it is with special interest that we should examine the following brief survey of the Industry. To make our subject clear we have divided it into four chapters. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Economics.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Major-third mixtures in the time of J.S. Bach : implications for organ performance and registration
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: La multi-percussion soliste est définie traditionnellement comme une seule personne jouant de deux ou plusieurs instruments à percussion, et c'est à la fin des années 1950 que cette pratique s'est établie en tant que discipline spécifique. Le présent document soutien que la multi-percussion soliste s'est développée comme une discipline hybride sous l'impulsion des compositeurs et interprètes, qui ont fait éclater les frontières techniques et expressives habituelles pour incorporer le medium électronique, tout comme des éléments provenant de la danse, du drame ou de l'art conceptuel. Le mémoire présent les résultats de trois études de cas qui documentent la manière dont j'ai repoussé les limites de mes propres pratiques d'interprète, grâce à plusieurs collaborations. Ces études de cas sont:1. Aphasia-Dialogue (2014) par M. Applebaum (cor. par D. Espinosa) 2. 150pF for body capacitance (2014) par H. Morales et D. Espinosa 3. Six Drawings by Randall (2012) par D. Adamcyk et D. Espinosa [...]

This paper presents the mixtures of organs known to Johann Sebastian Bach and the implications that these various mixtures have for organ performance and registration. Five organs built by four of the most important organ builders of early eighteenth-century Middle Germany (Tobias Heinrich Gottfried Trost, Gottfried Silbermann, Zacharias Hildebrandt, and Joachim Wagner) are discussed in the context of their mixtures, and whether or not they contain a major-third-sounding rank. The presence of a major-third-sounding rank in an organ creates a unique sound, and one that was familiar to J.S. Bach. As such, this unique sound is considered in the context of the organ works of Bach. This paper is divided into four chapters. The first includes an Introduction and Overview of the research problem and the mixtures of the five historic organs that were the subjects of the research. Chapter II discusses important issues to consider in the context of the major-third mixture: temperament of the instrument; and the texture, key, and mode of the composition being performed. Chapter III applies the research to performance practice. A detailed discussion of a recent performance on a twentieth-century North American organ is presented in the context of the major-third mixture. The topics of the second chapter are applied in the third, and further reflections of the practical application of the research are given. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Organ (Musical instrument) -- Registration.
Music theory -- History -- 17th century.
Music theory -- History -- 18th century.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Comparative anatomy of the great horned owl andwhistling swan.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The anatomy of birds has been the subject of many monographs and comparative treatises having for their aim the establishment of a classification based on natural or genetic affinity. Nesting habits, modes of progression, skeleton, and muscles have been examined in turn without arriving at a final settlement of the question. There are more species of birds than of mammals, but fewer definable orders. Birds as a whole present a degree of adaptive radiation such as is to be found in a single order of reptiles or of mammals, and this is expressed anatomically in the presence or absence, atrophy or hypertrophy of parts. The information on these matters is scattered and in some instances confused, and practically no anatomical research has been devoted to local Canadian birds. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Zoology.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Literary indecency in certain Roman satirists.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: "Never mind the why and wherefore" wrote Gilbert, a satirist. But such freedom from exnlanation cannot be demanded by a person writing, not satire, but about satire. Some reasons ought to be brought forward for the choice of subject matter for a thesis. Especially is this so when the subject chosen is one whioh, by its very title, might perhaps cause a reader to avoid it. Literary Indeoency may appear, in many ways, not a very pleasant topic, but surely it is just now an important one. The present century is much interested in the discussion of moral problems. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Latin.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The American novel since 1910.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Nobody who looks into the matter can doubt that some kind of change has occurred to American fiction within oomparatively reoent years. Just when this change came about is impossible to determine. It came gradually and was led up to by a series of publications which brought about the Modern Novel. But I am going to take the year 1910, arbitrarily, as a point about which to focus criticism and comment. Only as a point of departure in this utilitarian sense is the year 1916 to be understood; otherwise it has no significance. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: English.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Investigations on invertebrate digestion.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Although the subject of invertebrate digestion is not a new field of investigation most of the work that has been done is of recent date, and a vast amount of work as yet remainsuntouched. It was with this fact in mind that the present account of feeding, digesting, and assimilation in limulus polyphemus was undertaken. Ho mention of Limulus is made in the volume on metabolism of Wintersteins Comparative Physiology. The only experimental work that has been reported on the digestive processes in limulus was done by K. I. and H. S. Kattill. An advance notice of this was published in the Journal of Biological Chemistry, vol.XX.p.xxii. and will be mentioned later. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Zoology.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Variations in the acidity of pure gastric juice.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: More than one hundred years ago, in 1824, Frout discovered hydrochloric acid in the gastric juice, and a few years later, in 1852, Bidder and Schmidt demonstrated free hydrochloric acid in the stomach. The acidity of the gastric juice is due almost exclusively to the hydrochloric acid. This fact was established by older investigators and confirmed not longago by Frouin. According to Roseman the gastric juice does not contain sulphuric or phosphoric acids or their salts. The small amounts of sulphur and phosphorous that he recoveredin his analysis of pure gastric juice of dogs, originated from the protein, and were liberated during the ignition of the solids. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Physiology.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The mechanism of organic oxidation.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The work to be described in the following pages was originally intended to form a logical continuation of the extensive studies of Hatcher and co-workers on the subject of oxidation. The poignant need for such investigation is obvious from a consideration of the remarkable paucity of generalizations which may be made with regard to oxidation. This is due in the main to the high degree of complexity of most oxidative reactions, which renders their study extremely difficult, and to the deplorable lack of attention previously paid to the effects of temperature, concentration and condition of the medium in which the oxidation takes place. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Lucretius and his times.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: In any age, ancient or modern, the great majority are inclined to accept the doctrines, opinions and institutions current as the best possible, and if, perhaps, they are not in accord with them, they are nevertheless well-content to adopt a 'laisser-faire' attitude, considering as they do, the folly of the individual who seeks to oppose his frail strength and weak voice to the overwhelming weight of the things that are. Individuals there are, however, who are temperamentally and intellectually incapable of subscribing to opinions which are not based on fact and truth as they see it. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Lucretius Carus, Titus.
Latin.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The mechanism of the action of sulphurous acid on lignin and related compounds.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The necessity for a kinetic as opposed to a purely c1assical organo-chemioal approaoh to the lignin problem is emphasized. A summary is given of the ev1denoe for the presence in lignin of those chemical groupings which, if present, would be capable of reacting with sulphurous acid. The results obtained by studying the electrical conductivity over the temperature range 180 - 146 degrees C. of reaction mixtures of sulphurous acid and a large number of type oompounds is discussed together with data on the stability of the resultant sulphonic acids and the mobility of the equilibrium involved. The compounds investigated include saturated and unsaturated aldehydes, saturated and unsaturated ketones, cycllc ketones and phenols, substances in wh1ah an ethylene linkage is the only reactive group, furane derivatives and compounds containing pyrone rings. The study is then extended to theligno sulphonio acids and important deductions are made as to the mechanism of formation of these acids and their constitution. The results are further discussed as applied tothe process of sulphite pulp manufacture. The experimental procedure involved in the investigation is described in detail and the results tabulated.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The psychological implications of Mr. Bertrand Russell’s philosophy.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: No adequate or complete introduction to the philosophy of Russell can be given within the compass of a few pages, and, therefore, no such attemptwill be made. This study, itself, is an attempted introduction to his philosophy carried out chiefly from the psychological point of view. The immeediate intention here, therefore, is to briefly state the purpose of the whole discussion and to give some idea of the attitude in which the approach is made, while attempting at the same time to correct certain prejudices that frequently exist agairst the man and his work. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Russell, Bertrand, 1872-1970 -- Views on psychology.
Russell, Bertrand, 1872-1970.
Psychology.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The jurisdiction over merchant shipping within the British Empire.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: A very sensible fashion has taught us to look for the beginning of most things to the history of early Greece and Rome. Ships and sea laws are no exception, for Phoenicia, Rhodes and even Athens herself had become almost a memory before ever Julius Caesar brought his ships to the shores o"f Britain. Indeed it was only in the course of another thousand years, when commerce had moved very gradually west and north, that Britain took her place among the maritime nations of that little world. Our history hegins then, in a very small corner of the Mediterranean, where merchants boldly put to sea and lawyers sought to regulate disputes. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Economics.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Comparative studies in oxidation.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Since its discovery by Thenard in 1818, hydrogen peroxide has been extensively used as an oxidizing agent for organic compounds. Its chief advantage, when so employed, is the absence of all decomposition products, except water, when oxidation is complete. Such an advantage has been thoroughly grasped. with the result that a large number of investigators has entered the field in the hope of establishing a mechanism of hydrogen peroxide oxidation of organic compounds. An examinination of the literature will show that such investigations have been carried on indiscriminately with hydrogen peroxide in the presence of acid, alkali and various metallic ions acting as catalysts. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The mechanism of staphylococcus aureus localization inrabbit tissues.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The growth of certain micro-organisms in certain host tissues, and the failure of these same parasites to grow in other tissues of the same host is a well known phenomenon. Inexperimental staphylococcus infection of rabbits this apparent partiality of the coccus for certain tissues is well exemplified. The intravenous injection of a lethal dose of staphylococcus invariably shows at post mortem examination multiple abscesses in the kidneys and myocardium. Frequently one finds small abscesses in the skeletal muscle, particularly the abdominal wall, and in the smooth muscle of the gut tract; these are more often found when larger doses are employed. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Bacteriology.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: La France d'après-guerre, jugée par le romanaméricain.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: "Vous etes ignorants de la France intime" cachée derrière ses portes." Te11e est l'accusation portée par une Française dans le roman "Silent Storms" d'Ernest Poole.Est-ce vrai? Sommes-nous des Américains incapables de voir les forces cachees chez les Français modernes? Que disent nos romanciers à ce sujet? Car ce sont eux qui produisent en ce moment le type de 1itterature le plus populaire" et qui forment l'opinion, souvent sans y penser sur une nation entière à laquelle le peup1e Américain s'est toujours vivement interesse, surtout depuis 1a guerre. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: French.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The sorption of vapors by wood and cellulose.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The sorption of vapors by wood and cellulose is a oontinuation,and elaboration, of an investigation started in this laboratory, by Pidgeon and JMaass. Their work was oonfined to the sorption of water vapor by wood and cellulose, over an extended range of vapor pressures and temperatures. Further, a detailed study was made of the penetration of water vapor into wood. these investigators oon fined their attention to various samples of two ooniferous woods, and to a pure ootton cellulose, and examined these throughout the complete rangeof vapor pressures. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Elementary theory of quadratic forms.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: In order to make this thesis reasonably complete and yet keep within prescribed limits of space, it was considered best not to include any theorems on invariant factors of pairs of quadratic forms, on quadratic differential forms, or on quadratic forms in an infinite number of variables. Although the results included are for the most part well known, some of the proofs are new. Within the range to which this thesis is confined, perhaps no other single treatise has included all the propositions here collected. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Mathematics.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Frontier religious organization, with special reference tothe Peace River area.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: This study is an attempt to discover, and if possible, to measure certain tendencies in the field of frontier religious organization. The thesis is "There are types of religious organization which are peculiar to frontier environments". With this in mind, early frontiers of the United States were studied and the types of religious activity found therein. Then followed a comparison of frontier life of today with this early pattern, and it was found that the religious pattern of the modern frontier differs in many respects from the pattern of tke early frontier. Then the specific frontier of the study - namely, the Peace River - was subjected to a detailed study, in order to show the likenesses or differences to tke general pattern that had already been presented. The factors tkat influenced the growth and pattern of settlement of the area were dealt with in detail, thus showine the ecology of the area. With the ecological distribution presented, the next step was to trace the process of social interaction, in relation to the social organization or the area, particu1arly the re1igious phase of this organization. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Sociology.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Investigation of density of vapors in equilibrium withliquids.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The characteristic of a liquid to endeavor, at all times, to be in equilibrium with its own vapor gives rise to the phenomenon of vapor pressure. If the liquid is in an open vessel exposed to the atmosphere, ebullition will set in when the vapor pressure has reached a value of one atmosphere. However if the liquid be entirely enclosed and then heated above its normal boiling point no bubbles will result, but evaporation will take place silently and inconspicuously with the result that the amount in the vapor phase will increase with a rise in temperature. Finally a remarkable occurrence takes place. The meniscus dividing the two phases disappears and no longer can any distinction be made between vapor and liquid. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Studies in bacterial metabolism.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The synthesis of a polysaccharide (levan) from simpler carbohydrates both by the agency of Bacillus subtilis Cohn and Bacillus mesentericus Trevisan has been studied. The action of both these organisms is apparently specific in that they only bring about polysaccharide formation from sugars containing a terminal fructofuranose residue in their molecule. A similar synthesis can be carried out by employing the corresponding enzyme-preparation from Bacillus mesentericus. The bearing of these results on the known fact that yeast invertase only exerts its hydrolytic action on sugars containing a terminal fructofuranose group is discussed in detail. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Bacteriology.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The investigation of slime settling in Dorr thickeners.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Thickening or slime settling in metallurgical operations is the process of partially dewatering a mixture of finely ground solids and water by allowing the solids to settle from suspension in a large tank or thickener. This process of thickening is used in practically all modern ore treatment plants, and often in more than one phase of the operations.Thickening is also a necessary operation in many industrial processes and in sewage disposal. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Mining Engineering.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Morphology of the spruce saw-fly Diprion Polytomum Hartig.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The biology of the spruoe saw-fly is known to some extent, though there is apparently no literature on its morphology. This paper consists of a brief discussion of the externalmorphology of the four stages through which the insect passes, of some internal structures of ectodermal origin, and also of the internal morphology of the adult digestive andnervous systems, together with certain associated organs. The term spruce saw-fly as applied to the species is not a satisfactory one, it having been previously applied to another speoies, Diprion (Lophyrus) abietis, of the same family (Swaine '13 and 115). This term was adopted, however, at the time this study was undertaken, as the insect had not been identified at that time. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Entomology.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Histo-physiological studies on secretion in the salivary gland.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The early history of scientific description of the salivary gland is obscure. No doubt the intensive use of mercurial medicines and the consequent salivation induced had early directed the attention of the anatomist toward these glands in regard to their anatomy and relationships in gross. The landmarks of eponymic terminology record only the duct of Wharton (1610 - 73) - the submaxillary duct, the duct of Stenson (1638 - 1686) - the parotid duct, and the nerve of Jacobson (1783 - 1843). The investigation of the histology of the glands is much more recent and followed upon the physiological advances of the latter part of the last century. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Salivary glands -- Secretions.
Physiology.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Dramatic censorship in France and England, 1843-1909 : a study in comparative literature.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The censorship in England traced to the Master of Revels(1377); in France to an ordonnance against jongleurs(789). More arbitrary and traditional in England Patent Theatres' Act, 1843, confirmed the censorship'under the Lord Chamberlain, assisted by a permanent Examiner of Plays Select Committees, 1866 and 1909, reported on censorship. French censure depended on political changes, and was finally abolished in 1906. More persuasive and thorough than the English. The influence of the· stage on public 'morale; evidence showing the French more excitable and amenable to suggestion. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Theater -- Censorship -- Great Britain.
English.
Theater -- Censorship -- France.
